signal_inventory.id_collision_note: F1/F4/F6 and F3 files both use 001-025 range. Graded IDs disambiguate with source tag.

graded_signals.title: GPT-4 equivalent inference at $0.40/M tokens with 50x annual decline rate

supports: Baumol cure economics across all cognitive-labor sectors
Near-zero marginal cost for routine cognitive tasks by 2027
Jevons expansion of addressable AI task universe

graded_signals.transformation_implications: The single most powerful force in the current transformation. At 50x/yr decline, inference costs reach sub-$0.10/M tokens by mid-2026. Every sector with routine cognitive labor becomes a Baumol cure candidate. This signal underpins ALL sector transformation projections.

graded_signals.title: $936B-$1.8T PE refinancing wall maturing 2026-2028 — distress catalyst for Schumpeterian replacement

data_sources: Moody's leveraged finance maturity wall report
supports: 2026-2028 acquisition window at distressed multiples
PE portfolio companies face simultaneous refinancing + AI disruption
Schumpeterian replacement mechanism for leveraged incumbents
contradicts: Amend-and-extend activity may soften the wall timing

graded_signals.transformation_implications: This is the MECHANISM through which Schumpeterian replacement occurs in cognitive-labor sectors. PE distress at 11.98% (+148% from baseline) creates forced sales. AI-native acquirers can purchase revenue streams at distressed multiples. The 2026-2028 window has a definite opening (refinancing wall starts) and closing (survivors adapt/fail).

graded_signals.title: Financial Services cascade accelerating: 54% customer interactions automated, 87% AI fraud detection, 339 branch closures

supports: Phase transition from early_disruption to acceleration for NAICS 52
Back-office automation nearly complete, front-office next
Physical footprint rationalization accelerating

graded_signals.transformation_implications: RECOMMEND PHASE UPGRADE: Financial Services (NAICS 52) from 'early_disruption' to 'acceleration'. This is the engine's FIRST sector to reach acceleration phase. All automation metrics above 50%. Evidence is converging from 7+ independent sources. The cascade is self-reinforcing: automation -> branch closure -> headcount reduction -> further automation.

graded_signals.title: Staffing industry stocks RHI -53%, MAN -44%, KELYA -25% — fastest sector transformation confirmed

data_sources: RHI, MAN, KELYA stock price data
supports: Administrative Services (NAICS 56) in acceleration phase
Staffing intermediation layer becoming redundant
Precedes and predicts similar declines in accounting, legal, insurance

graded_signals.transformation_implications: The staffing industry is the first complete Schumpeterian cascade visible in real-time. Stock price collapse -> revenue collapse -> employment collapse sequence is the classic prediction. This is the strongest canary signal for the broader cognitive-labor transformation. 3.57M employees and $192.7B wages at stake.

graded_signals.title: Coasean shrinkage at 532K new business applications/month — structural shift toward micro-firms

supports: Optimal firm size decreasing across cognitive-labor sectors
AI agents enabling 1-3 person firms to operate at enterprise scale
Sustained through 2022-2026 rate cycle — structural, not cyclical

graded_signals.transformation_implications: 532K/month is the empirical confirmation of Coasean shrinkage theory. AI reduces transaction costs that justified large firms. This creates structural demand for AI tools/platforms enabling micro-firm operations. Combined with staffing destruction, signals a fundamental restructuring of firm size distribution in the economy.

graded_signals.title: Healthcare AI adoption 3%->22% in 2 years, 66% physician usage, 295 FDA clearances in 2025

supports: Healthcare transformation faster than expected
Physician-tool adoption pathway bypassing patient trust barrier
FDA regulatory pathway proven and accelerating
contradicts: F5 Psychology: patient trust gap remains at 34 points — limits patient-facing AI

graded_signals.transformation_implications: RECOMMEND: Upgrade Healthcare (NAICS 62) phase_confidence from 'medium' to 'high'. The trust barrier is being circumvented through physician-invisible AI. The 295 FDA clearances in 2025 alone (vs 950 cumulative through Aug 2024) represents a massive acceleration. Healthcare is transforming faster through the 'back door' than the 'front door'.

graded_signals.title: 73K cobots shipped 2025 (+31% YoY), $2.26B Q1 2026 robotics funding — physical production cost curve bending

supports: Robotics x AI compound effect accelerating beyond prior projections
74-point implementation gap = massive services opportunity
COGS compression wave forming in manufacturing

graded_signals.transformation_implications: P-006 (Robotics x AI Compound) is accelerating. The 74-point gap between utilization (94%) and production readiness (20%) represents the central manufacturing business opportunity. Combined with Silver Tsunami (52.3% boomer-owned) and $2.26B Q1 funding, manufacturing transformation is entering a new phase.

graded_signals.title: Silver Tsunami: 2.34M businesses owned by 55+ with 58% no succession plan

data_sources: Census Bureau Survey of Business Owners
supports: Largest business transfer event in US economic history
Acquisition multiple compression in fragmented sectors
AI-native operators replacing legacy processes at acquisition

graded_signals.transformation_implications: The supply of acquirable businesses will far exceed organic buyer demand during 2026-2032 peak transfer window. Combined with PE refinancing wall and robotics x AI compound effect, this creates a 'triple convergence' for manufacturing acquisition: retiring owners + distressed prices + technology modernization opportunity.

graded_signals.title: DeepSeek R1 trained for ~$6M claimed o1 parity — Chinese LLM share surged 3% to 13% in 2 months

supports: Global AI ecosystem bifurcation (US proprietary vs China open-source)
Open-source AI closing frontier gap in 6-12 months
Developing world may adopt Chinese AI infrastructure
contradicts: US chip controls as durable competitive advantage

graded_signals.transformation_implications: DeepSeek shattered two assumptions: (1) that chip controls maintain durable US AI lead, and (2) that frontier AI requires massive compute. This accelerates Coasean shrinkage (any firm can access near-frontier AI) and accelerates the global AI bifurcation pattern. Business models predicated on exclusive frontier access have 6-12 month windows.

graded_signals.title: Baumol stored energy reaches $207B — professional services wage growth +4%/yr vs CPI 2.5% with gap widening

supports: Self-reinforcing Baumol dynamics: high wages -> AI viable -> professionals leave -> wages rise further
974K establishments and $1.07T payroll at stake
Pipeline collapse (CPA -33%, nursing -78K) compounds the force

graded_signals.transformation_implications: The $207B stored energy is conservative and GROWING annually. The 1.5pp annual spread between wage growth (4%) and CPI (2.5%) means the force accelerates every year it goes unreleased. Combined with pipeline collapse, this creates a self-reinforcing cycle that makes AI automation economics more favorable with each passing year.

graded_signals.title: Manufacturing AI implementation gap: 98% exploring / 20% ready = 78-point gap, $34B->$155B market

supports: Largest implementation services opportunity in any sector
50% can't identify right technology = advisory/consulting demand
4.5x TAM expansion in 5 years provides economic force

graded_signals.transformation_implications: The 78-point explore-ready gap is the single largest implementation opportunity identified. 50% can't identify right technology + 39% lack expertise + 32% face budget overruns = structural demand for AI integration services in manufacturing. This is NOT a technology problem — it is a deployment/integration problem.

graded_signals.title: Global AI ecosystem bifurcation: US subscription vs China free-access, Gulf as third compute node

supports: Two distinct AI ecosystem models forming globally
Gulf positioning as neutral compute zone
Developing world may adopt Chinese free-access AI stack

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Most significant structural finding for geographic dimension. A bifurcated global AI ecosystem means: (1) US-stack businesses may not translate to developing world markets; (2) AI compliance/interoperability between ecosystems becomes a business category; (3) Gulf compute infrastructure could bridge ecosystems. ALL geographic profiles need updating.

graded_signals.title: Grid interconnection bottleneck: 2,600 GW in 5+ year queues — THE binding constraint on AI scaling

supports: Physical infrastructure is the binding constraint on AI transformation, not AI capability
Geographic winners/losers based on grid capacity
Grid access as Ricardian factor of production
contradicts: Private grid infrastructure (behind-the-meter) may soften constraint for hyperscalers

graded_signals.transformation_implications: The most underappreciated constraint on AI transformation. 2,600 GW waiting (2x+ current US installed base) with 5+ year waits. This creates geographic winners (Texas ERCOT, Southeast, Gulf states) and losers (Northern Virginia). The grid bottleneck will persist through 2030 and constrains transformation velocity more than any other factor.

graded_signals.title: Professional pipeline collapse: CPA candidates -33%, nursing 78K vacancies->200K by 2030, 42 states teacher shortages

data_sources: National Council of State Boards of Nursing
supports: Generational rejection of Baumol-afflicted professions
Structural labor shortages that cannot be resolved by wages alone
AI augmentation becomes necessity, not choice
contradicts: Fear of AI replacing professionals paradoxically WORSENS pipeline — potential vicious cycle

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Multiple professional pipelines collapsing simultaneously. This is NOT cyclical — it is generational. The combination of above-CPI wage growth making professions expensive AND pipeline collapse making them scarce creates a structural necessity for AI augmentation. Regulatory barriers to AI in these professions will weaken under shortage pressure.

graded_signals.title: Global defense spending $2,718B (+9.4% real), steepest rise since Cold War; NATO 5% GDP target by 2035

supports: Defense spending supercycle confirmed (10th consecutive year of increase)
European rearmament +83% in decade
NATO 5% GDP target implies $1.2-1.5T European defense spending

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Defense spending supercycle is a multi-decade structural commitment. $13.4B DoD AI/autonomy dedicated line (first ever) + European rearmament +83% + NATO 5% GDP target = the largest government spending commitment outside AI infrastructure. Defense AI is entering acceleration phase. Creates massive demand for autonomous systems, AI/ML, cybersecurity.

graded_signals.title: AI adoption plateau at 46% for 12 months — psychology ceiling, not technology limitation

data_sources: Deloitte State of AI in the Enterprise
supports: Adoption is psychology-limited, not technology-limited
Two-speed economy forming: 46% adopters gain 20-40% productivity advantage
54% non-adopters represent $200B+ services market for trusted AI intermediaries
contradicts: Technology improvements alone will not break the plateau — psychology interventions required

graded_signals.transformation_implications: The 46% plateau is unprecedented in technology adoption history. AI triggers identity/role fears that previous technologies did not. Breaking through requires psychology interventions (trusted partners, proven playbooks, regulatory clarity). The 54% non-adopters are the largest untapped market for AI implementation services.

graded_signals.title: 25-40% of Google code AI-generated, Copilot 41% acceptance — software labor cost curve bending

supports: Structural shift in software labor economics
$200B+ global software development cost compression
Baumol cure for software development sector

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Software development is experiencing its own Baumol cure. 30-40% productivity increase means same output at 60-70% labor hours. For sectors dependent on custom software (fintech, healthtech, logistics), this removes a primary cost barrier. For the software industry itself, wage growth above CPI becomes unsustainable as AI-augmented developers produce 2-3x output.

graded_signals.title: Gulf SWFs committing $100B+ to AI infrastructure: Saudi Humain $77B, UAE MGX $25B, NEOM suspended

supports: Oil-to-AI wealth conversion as largest capital reallocation in recent history
Gulf becoming primary AI infrastructure provider, not just consumer
Below-market cost of capital creating artificial compute cost advantages
contradicts: Execution timeline uncertain — commitments clear but operational capability unproven

graded_signals.transformation_implications: MENA geographic profile requires major upgrade. These are not secondary AI markets — they are becoming primary infrastructure providers. The speed of reallocation (NEOM suspended within months of Humain launch) demonstrates SWF agility. Creates compute availability that could democratize AI access for Africa and South Asia.

graded_signals.title: Healthcare AI trust gap: providers 7/10 vs patients 3.6/10 — 34-point gap defines adoption ceiling

data_sources: Pew Research Center AI in Healthcare 2025
supports: Trust ceiling constrains which healthcare AI applications can scale
Back-office AI scales because patients never interact with it
Human-in-the-loop becomes permanent architecture for clinical AI
contradicts: 3%->22% adoption suggests trust barrier is being circumvented, not blocking

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Defines the healthcare AI adoption pathway: back-office first, clinical-with-oversight second, autonomous clinical last (if ever). The trust gap creates structural demand for AI explainability, patient consent, and verification services. Trust-building itself becomes a market category.

graded_signals.title: Fear-driven demand creates ~$86B market by 2030: governance $15.8B + safety $9.8B + cybersecurity $60.6B

data_sources: Grand View Research AI Safety forecast
Fortune Business Insights Cybersecurity AI forecast
supports: Psychology is an economic force creating markets, not just a friction
Fear creates demand proportional to fear intensity
EU AI Act creates largest fear economy market due to regulatory demand

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Fear is a force, not just a barrier. Every sector with high fear friction simultaneously creates demand for fear-mitigation services. The $86B fear economy is as real as the $207B Baumol stored energy. This is the core v3 insight about F5: psychology creates markets. FEAR_ECONOMY category models should reference this signal.

graded_signals.title: CRE office vacancy at record 20.1%, $929B debt maturing — second-order cascade from AI headcount reduction

supports: Second-order cascade from AI headcount reduction + remote work
Regional bank stress vector (70% of CRE loans held by regional banks)
Adaptive reuse and distressed CRE acquisition opportunities

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Classic second-order cascade chain: AI headcount reduction -> office vacancy -> CRE debt distress -> bank exposure -> regional bank stress -> credit tightening. Creates both risk (credit tightening for small businesses) and opportunity (CRE acquisition at distressed prices). Demonstrates how sector transformations cascade across the economy.

graded_signals.title: $600-700B hyperscaler AI capex in 2026 — Perez Installation overshoot guarantees cheap infrastructure

supports: Perez Installation overshoot creates cheap infrastructure for deployment-phase builders
Supply-side cost pressure for 3+ years guaranteed
Widening gap between frontier training cost and inference cost

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Classic Installation period overshoot. Hyperscalers building far more capacity than current demand justifies. The overshoot GUARANTEES cheap infrastructure for deployment-phase builders. Optimal position is deployment layer (using infrastructure others built), not infrastructure layer (competing to build more).

graded_signals.title: Accounting entering displacement peak (Phase 2, 2026-2028) — AI can do most staff accountant work now

supports: 2026-2028 is the Schumpeterian gap entry window for accounting
AI capable of tax prep, audit reconciliation, financial statements NOW
First affected: bookkeepers, payroll, entry-level accounting
contradicts: Low unemployment (2.0%) suggests market hasn't priced in displacement yet

graded_signals.transformation_implications: We are at the Phase 1 to Phase 2 transition. This IS the Schumpeterian gap entry window the engine identifies as optimal. Business models that help firms navigate Phase 2 (2026-2028) have best timing. Models providing advisory/strategic capabilities for Phase 3 are well-positioned for the new equilibrium.

graded_signals.title: Consumer sentiment collapsed: Michigan 57.3 (4-year low), CEO Confidence 84.5 (12-year low)

data_sources: University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index Feb 2026
Conference Board CEO Confidence Survey Q1 2026
supports: Macro-psychological headwind slowing AI investment 6-12 months
Counter-cyclical investment window for firms that invest during trough
Sentiment recovery will create pent-up adoption surge
contradicts: Structural forces (cost collapse, pipeline collapse, demographic pressure) are stronger than sentiment

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Creates a TIMING GAP: AI technology is more capable than ever but macro psychology is worst in years. Companies that invest counter-cyclically gain first-mover advantage when sentiment recovers. Sentiment collapse AMPLIFIES sector-specific fear frictions. This is a headwind, not a reversal.

graded_signals.title: Japan population decline accelerated to ~900K/year (2024) — fastest recorded, recalibrating leading indicator

supports: Japan is 5-7 years ahead (tighter than prior 5-10 estimate)
Automation-of-necessity path: labor shortage forces adoption regardless of psychology
Japan solutions become export products (elder care robotics, automated logistics)

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Japan's accelerating decline tightens the leading indicator window from 5-10 years to 5-7 years. Japan demonstrates the endgame for aging economies: automation is not optional but necessary for economic survival. The solutions Japan develops under demographic pressure become exportable to US, EU, China as they follow the same trajectory.

graded_signals.title: Reshoring paradox: record capital ($40.9B Mexico, $19B India) but US output only +1%, Kearney Index -311

supports: 2-5 year investment-to-production lag for physical infrastructure
Mexico nearshoring capacity tapped out
India emerging as primary alternative
Manufacturers reverting to Asian sourcing despite rhetoric
contradicts: Record FDI suggests commitment is real even if output lags

graded_signals.transformation_implications: The reshoring rhetoric-reality gap creates business opportunities in transition management, temporary Asian sourcing optimization, India manufacturing facilitation, and Mexico infrastructure expansion. Manufacturing models must account for 2-5 year lag between capital commitment and operational output.

graded_signals.title: CHIPS Act fabs entering production: Intel 1.8nm HVM, TSMC Arizona volume, Samsung Taylor >90% complete

supports: US semiconductor manufacturing becoming real
Reduces Taiwan concentration risk for leading-edge chips
Intel Ohio delay shows greenfield project challenges
contradicts: Intel Ohio delay to 2030 shows pace is uneven and slower than announced

graded_signals.transformation_implications: CHIPS Act producing mixed results: Intel 1.8nm is a genuine milestone (first US sub-2nm fab), but Intel Ohio delay echoes Kearney reshoring pattern. $19.21B in subsidies deployed. US semiconductor supply chain diversification is happening but unevenly. Taiwan concentration risk being partially addressed.

graded_signals.title: Global robot installations projected 575K in 2025 (+6%), density doubled to 162 per 10K — China surpassed Germany/Japan

supports: Robot density doubling validates P-006 compound effect
China surpassing Germany/Japan in density changes nearshoring calculus
Asia's 74% deployment share means most robotics innovation is in Asia

graded_signals.transformation_implications: China's robot density surpassing Germany/Japan has major implications for nearshoring. If China automates faster than reshoring destinations, Chinese manufacturing cost advantage may INCREASE rather than decrease. Nearshoring driven by geopolitical risk, not cost advantage.

graded_signals.title: Sector resistance map: education 55% uncomfortable, legal 82% ethical concern, healthcare 34-pt trust gap

data_sources: Pew Research AI and Education Survey 2025
supports: Fear friction creates regulatory moats for first movers
High-fear sectors adopt 2-4 years behind financial services
Incumbents with existing trust have advantage in high-fear sectors
contradicts: Financial services at 73% proves fear is curable through familiarity

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Core v3 insight: psychology determines not just adoption SPEED but competitive STRUCTURE. High-fear sectors adopt slowly but create stronger moats for first movers. The fear friction that slows adoption ALSO raises barriers to entry for competitors. This is the strategic insight for FEAR_ECONOMY business models.

graded_signals.title: Magnificent 7 at 33% of S&P 500 — concentration creates systemic fragility linked to AI narrative

supports: Late Installation speculation creating fragility
Correction beneficial for deployment-layer businesses
Passive investment flows amplify concentration dynamics

graded_signals.transformation_implications: Where Minsky and Perez converge. A correction at the Installation-to-Deployment transition is historically normal and BENEFICIAL for deployment-layer businesses: reduces talent costs, lowers cloud compute pricing, creates acquisition opportunities. The $500B Nvidia wipeout on DeepSeek is a preview.

Manufacturing implementation gap (98%/20%) confirms that technology is NOT the bottleneck — deployment is.

pattern_updates.notes: Strongest pattern in registry. $207B stored energy growing at 1.5pp/yr. Pipeline collapse (CPA -33%, nursing 78K) deepens the force. AI code generation (25-40% at Google) confirms Baumol cure in software sector. 5 new supporting signals this cycle, zero contradictions.

Metrics unchanged (52.3%, 2.34M, 58% no succession). Japan acceleration (~900K/yr decline) tightens the leading indicator from 5-10 to 5-7 years ahead. EU gradient data (Germany 47.8, Italy 48.4 vs France 42) adds geographic precision.

Accelerating beyond prior projections. 73K cobots (+31% YoY), 55% factory adoption, $2.26B Q1 funding. Robot density doubled globally (162/10K). China surpassed Germany/Japan at 470/10K. $34B->$155B manufacturing AI TAM (4.5x). Physical AI doubling from 9% to 22% in 2 years.

Capital rotation to physical/industrial confirmed. Reshoring capital flowing ($40.9B Mexico, $19B India) despite output lag. Robot density doubling. Manufacturing AI market at 35.3% CAGR. Defense spending supercycle adds physical infrastructure demand.
No new evidence this cycle. Freshness penalty applies (2 cycles without new evidence). Wholesale (NAICS 42) remains zero-funded AI startups. Pattern maintained but should be refreshed next cycle.

This is the engine's most evidence-rich pattern. RECOMMEND sector phase transition from early_disruption to acceleration.

transition_criteria_met.employment_change: Accounting employment -49K YoY confirmed. 819K jobs posted but 61% can't fill = skill mismatch deepening.
transition_criteria_met.canary_stocks: RHI -53%, MAN -44% (both >25% decline). 2 canary stocks confirmed.
transition_criteria_met.nash_equilibrium_break: 54% of customer interactions automated. Banks that don't automate face structural cost disadvantage. Nash equilibrium broken: non-adoption is now the risky strategy.
transition_criteria_met.additional_evidence: 87% AI fraud detection with 92% interception. 60% digital lending AI-driven. 339 branch closures in 2025. RPA $8.62B transitioning to AI agents. Back-office nearly complete, front-office next.

fear_friction_assessment.notes: Financial services has LOWEST fear friction (73% adoption). Psychology is NOT a barrier here. The control group for what adoption looks like without fear friction.

sector_phase_assessments.phase_transition: No phase change. Deepening within early_disruption phase.

transition_criteria_met.employment_change: CPA candidates -33%, accounting graduates -17% = pipeline collapse. But employment still at 2.0% unemployment = pre-displacement.
transition_criteria_met.canary_stocks: Staffing canary confirmed (RHI -53%, adjacent sector). Direct professional services stock canary not yet triggered.
transition_criteria_met.nash_equilibrium_break: Not yet fully broken. 46% adoption plateau suggests many firms still not adopting.
transition_criteria_met.additional_evidence: Professional services wages +4%/yr vs CPI 2.5% = $207B automatable wages growing. Accounting entering displacement peak (Phase 2, 2026-2028). AI can do most staff accountant work now.

fear_friction_assessment.notes: Legal 82% ethical concerns, Education 55% uncomfortable. Professional associations (ABA, AICPA) create institutional resistance. But economic pressure from clients overwhelms institutional preferences.

sector_phase_assessments.phase_transition: No phase change. Deepening within early_disruption with strong acceleration indicators.

transition_criteria_met.employment_change: No significant employment decline yet. Silver Tsunami creating exits, not layoffs.
transition_criteria_met.canary_stocks: No manufacturing canary stock decline. Manufacturing ETF stable.
transition_criteria_met.nash_equilibrium_break: 98% exploring but only 20% ready — Nash equilibrium not yet broken because adoption is not yet competitive necessity.
transition_criteria_met.additional_evidence: 73K cobots (+31% YoY), $34B->$155B TAM, robot density doubled, China surpassed Germany/Japan. Physical AI doubling (9%->22%). But the 78-point implementation gap means acceleration requires closing the deployment barrier, not just technology availability.

fear_friction_assessment.notes: Manufacturing has LOW fear friction (94% utilizing AI). The barrier is implementation complexity (50% can't identify right technology, 39% lack expertise), not psychology. This is a deployment/integration problem.

sector_phase_assessments.phase_transition: No phase change but CONFIDENCE UPGRADE: medium -> high

transition_criteria_met.employment_change: 78K unfilled RN positions, projected 200K by 2030. Pipeline collapse, not displacement.
transition_criteria_met.canary_stocks: No healthcare canary stock decline detected.
transition_criteria_met.nash_equilibrium_break: Not yet broken broadly, but 66% physician AI usage suggests bottom-up adoption creating competitive pressure.
transition_criteria_met.additional_evidence: 3%->22% adoption in 2 years (extraordinary acceleration). 295 FDA clearances in 2025. 71% hospitals running predictive AI. Mayo Clinic 40% readmission reduction. Trust barrier being circumvented via physician-tool pathway. Telehealth AI $5.2B->$119.3B.

fear_friction_assessment.notes: CONTEXT-DEPENDENT fear friction. Admin AI: LOW. Physician-tool AI: LOW-MEDIUM. Patient-facing AI: HIGH (34-point trust gap). The invisible AI pathway circumvents the trust barrier. Exposure effect suggests barriers erode over 2-4 years.

sector_phase_assessments.phase_transition: No phase change. Already in acceleration. Deepening.

transition_criteria_met.canary_stocks: RHI -53%, MAN -44%, KELYA -25% — strongest canary signal in any sector.
transition_criteria_met.nash_equilibrium_break: Fully broken. Staffing intermediation becoming redundant as AI handles tasks directly.
transition_criteria_met.additional_evidence: 3.57M employees, $192.7B wages at stake. Coasean shrinkage (532K business apps/mo) accelerates the destruction of the intermediation layer.

fear_friction_assessment.notes: Fear friction is moderate but irrelevant — the sector is being destroyed regardless of psychology. Workers in staffing industry are not resisting AI; the businesses are losing demand as enterprises adopt AI directly.

transition_criteria_met.nash_equilibrium_break: Not applicable — high tacit-manual content means AI augments rather than replaces.
transition_criteria_met.additional_evidence: Data center construction demand surging. Trades shortage worsening. AI augmentation opportunity but Baumol Premium, not Cure.

fear_friction_assessment.notes: Construction is psychology-NEUTRAL to AI. Psychological readiness exceeds economic readiness because the sector needs workers so badly that any augmentation is welcome. This is Baumol Premium territory.

sector_phase_assessments.phase_transition: No phase change. Still zero AI startup density.

transition_criteria_met.canary_stocks: No canary stocks identified for wholesale trade.
transition_criteria_met.nash_equilibrium_break: Not broken — zero AI startups means no competitive pressure to adopt.
transition_criteria_met.additional_evidence: 122K establishments. Coasean shrinkage in the sector is the primary force. AI intermediation replacing human brokers is theoretical, not observed.

fear_friction_assessment.notes: No measurable fear friction — the sector is simply underserved by AI solutions. Zero-density Schumpeterian gap means transformation will be sudden when it starts.

us.notes: Strongest data coverage. All 6 forces well-characterized. Primary concern: second-order cascade effects undermodeled.

japan.notes: Population decline data upgraded (900K/yr). Robot density well-documented. Service sector transformation poorly characterized.

china.notes: Significantly upgraded. AI ecosystem bifurcation well-documented. Robot density, DeepSeek, Huawei Ascend data. Enterprise adoption data conflicting.

eu.notes: AI Act uncertainty primary driver. Aging gradient now characterized. Defense spending data strong. AI adoption data weak.

india.notes: Upgraded. Manufacturing FDI data strong. Demographic dividend quantified. PLI results documented. AI adoption data limited.

latam.notes: Mexico FDI record documented. Nearshoring capacity constraints identified. Brazil and Argentina data gaps. AI adoption data minimal.

sea.notes: Least characterized region. Manufacturing migration from China noted but country-specific data weak. Vietnam, Indonesia mentioned but not quantified.

mena.notes: Significantly upgraded from 0.35. Gulf SWF AI pivot extensively documented ($100B+). Saudi Humain, UAE MGX, Abu Dhabi campus all sourced. Operational execution data lacking.

cascade_triggers_fired.notes: Solar LCOE has reached $0.02/kWh ($20/MWh) in optimal locations. This fires the energy model recalculation trigger. All compute-dependent and energy-intensive business models should be recalculated with updated energy cost assumptions.

The PE refinancing wall exceeds the $300B annual threshold when annualized ($312B-$600B per year across 2026-2028). Recommend firing this trigger to recalculate all PE cascade models including acquisition timing, distress pricing, and sector-specific PE exposure.

state_update_recommendations.justification: 9 independent signals confirm acceleration criteria: 5+ signals (9), employment change (accounting -49K YoY, 61% hiring difficulty), canary stocks (RHI -53%, MAN -44%), Nash equilibrium break (54% interactions automated, non-adoption is now risky). This is the engine's first sector to reach acceleration phase.

3%->22% adoption in 2 years, 66% physician usage (+78% YoY), 295 FDA clearances in 2025 (vs 950 cumulative to Aug 2024), 71% hospitals running predictive AI. Trust barrier being circumvented through physician-tool pathway. Evidence now strongly supports early_disruption phase.

First quantitative assessment complete. AI adoption plateau at 46% for 12 months. Consumer sentiment collapsed (Michigan 57.3). Fear-driven demand creating $86B market. Generational divide documented. Financial services 73% adoption as control group. Velocity is 'decelerating' meaning adoption momentum is slowing due to psychology factors.

F6 now fully characterized. Grid bottleneck is THE binding constraint (2,600 GW in queue). Nuclear renaissance 10GW+. Solar at $0.02-0.03/kWh. Renewable investment $1.1T exceeds fossil fuel. Data centers at 4%+ of US grid. All metrics confirm accelerating energy demands with constrained supply — force is accelerating.
Fed has cut to 3.50-3.75% after 4 cuts in 2025. State.json shows outdated 4.33% value. Update to current rate.

cycle_summary.headline: v3-2 is the engine's most data-rich cycle: 84 signals across all 6 force dimensions, with first quantitative data for F5 Psychology and F6 Energy. Financial Services recommended for phase upgrade to acceleration (first sector). Healthcare confidence upgraded. 5 new patterns identified. 2 cascade triggers fired/approaching.
key_findings: FINANCIAL SERVICES CASCADE ACCELERATING: All automation metrics above 50%. 54% customer interactions automated, 87% AI fraud detection, 339 branch closures. FIRST SECTOR recommended for acceleration phase.
HEALTHCARE AI FASTER THAN EXPECTED: 3%->22% adoption in 2 years via physician-invisible AI pathway. 295 FDA clearances in 2025. Trust barrier circumvented, not eliminated.

F5 PSYCHOLOGY CHARACTERIZED: AI adoption plateau at 46% for 12 months proves adoption is psychology-limited, not technology-limited. $86B fear economy by 2030. 34-point healthcare trust gap. Generational divide (Gen Z 67% vs Boomer 29%).

F6 ENERGY CHARACTERIZED: Grid bottleneck (2,600 GW in 5+ year queues) is THE binding constraint on AI scaling. Nuclear renaissance 10GW+. Solar at all-time low. Renewable investment exceeds fossil fuel.
GLOBAL AI BIFURCATION: Two-ecosystem model forming (US proprietary vs China open-source/free). Chinese LLM share 3%->13% in 2 months. Gulf as potential third compute node with $100B+.
DEFENSE SPENDING SUPERCYCLE: $2.72T global (+9.4%), NATO 5% GDP target, DoD $13.4B AI/autonomy dedicated line. European rearmament +83% in a decade.
PE REFINANCING WALL APPROACHING: $936B-$1.8T maturing 2026-2028. PE distress rate 11.98%. Creates 2-3 year acquisition window for AI-native competitors.
CONSUMER SENTIMENT COLLAPSED: Michigan 57.3 (4-yr low), CEO Confidence 84.5 (12-yr low). Creates counter-cyclical investment window but slows adoption 6-12 months.
MANUFACTURING IMPLEMENTATION GAP: 98% exploring / 20% ready = 78-point gap. $34B->$155B market. The barrier is deployment, not technology.
RESHORING RHETORIC VS REALITY: Kearney -311 despite $40.9B Mexico FDI + $19B India FDI. 2-5 year lag between investment and production.

PRIORITY 2: Fire PE refinancing wall trigger and recalculate PE cascade models

PRIORITY 5: Deepen F3 geographic profiles — SEA confidence at 0.35 is the largest gap. India and EU data also need strengthening

PRIORITY 6: Construct business models for the 5 new patterns (P-028 through P-032): bifurcation interoperability, reshoring transition services, defense AI, Gulf compute services, healthcare invisible AI
PRIORITY 7: Refresh P-022 (Zero-Density Schumpeterian Gaps) — no new evidence for 2 cycles, freshness penalty applied
PRIORITY 8: Quantify defense AI as a sector transformation entry (NAICS 92/336) — data is strong enough to justify tracking
